content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												My god, This game. I cant belive that i missed it when it was released, this game is just pure greatness. I think this is the best "mount and blade" game in the series. Its kinda similar to the last game , "Mount and blade : warband", but new additions are improved graphics and guns. Gunplay really makes this game unique as the combat in this game is best i have seen in a while. You fire your inaccurate musket or bow from range, and on close combat you try to kill your enemies with a sword, and block enemys attacks, if you master the timing, you can easily take down large group of enemies. It adds bit of reality and cool skill ceiling to the game.In singleplayer, you start as a little poor villager, you can Travel around the map, Take quests , trade ,rob caravans, besiege castles , recruit men and much more. When you start to Get some money and experience , you will start to Get better gear and armor, and you start expanding your army. You can ally with factions and conquer the other factions. Its awesome when at start you rob small bandit groups with your Little army of mens recruited from villages, and after some time, you have army of 100 of mens, and you Attack an enemy faction castle along with your Friendly Armies. Singleplayer is like big sandbox, you can just be trader and make loads of profits, you can be bandit and rob caravans, you can create your own faction and conquer lands, or ally with other factions and eliminate others. You can get hours and hours and hours of fun.    This game also has really entertaining multiplayer, first you create the way your multiplayer character looks like, then you hop in the battle. Usually there are about 50 players in same match, other team is defending castle and other is attacking it. You can buy equiment like better armor with gold (you get more gold when you get kills). There are also classic deathmatch , battle and other game modes. I just love the multiplayer, it feels amazing when musketeers fire their muskets and throw their grenades and trough the smoke charges cavalry trying to stab poor foot soldiers and as the armies meet begins hectic sword play.     Also, this game has really active mod community which helps this game survive on the long runI Cant recommend this game enough , it really is worth the price

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												What can I say about this game?UPDATE!!!!: While the gameplay itself is absolutely phenominal, there is a MAJOR drawback that I discovered once I was finally given a castle to oversee. Beyond the challenge of getting your best friend, the King, to give you a little slice to call your own, when the budget screen shows up for each town/castle/village you own, instead of putting every tariff and expense on a single sheet with a breakdown of each category as was done in basic Warband, here they point out to you EACH AND EVERY thing you have had built, and every person you have had hired for EACH AND EVERY town, castle, and village. As I mentioned in my first review, there are a lot of options for each location you own. Now imagine every week in game, you are bombarded by a 30 page dissertation of every individual expansion you have ordered. It makes the game *almost* unplayable. This is the only major drawback of the game that I have found. If you can cope with this first paragraph, read on and see why I would still reccommend keeping a dictionary handy to check your sperling and that you should purchase Mount and Blade with Fire and Sword!It's fan-freaking-tastic!!I loved the original, but lets face it, there comes a point when there is no more challenge or suprise to obliterating your opponents on the field of battle. That game was drying up for me, it was finished.Then this little gem appeared, and the love was reborn!The game is the same concept; pick a faction, crush the opposition.What makes this game so great? They give you freaking muskets, pistols, and grenades!The reload spead is faster than reality, but who wants to stand around reloading all the time?But the powder weapons, even at their worst stats are devastating. The grenades are a lot of fun, but leave a bit to be desired. You can choose from three different sizes: Small medium and large. (Sounds like a freaking fast food menu, right?) The problem with each of them is they do not replenish after each battle as bullets and arrows do. But hey, they're already OP, so theres gotta be a drawback somewhere, right? Now here's where I have an issue with the game: Some unknown set of circumstances casues them to explode but do no damage. (Believe me, Im not missing. When you are taking the walls and you are the first one up, get to the top of the ladder and look down at the horde waiting for you [units set at 150]. You cant miss a target like that if you tried. So after the first two grenades, the rest seem to stop working.) But with any of the three types of grenades, you can expect 3-4 kills with one throw. Oh! There is nothing more satisfying than watching a surge of blood-thirsty warriors coming at you with every ounce of confidence that you are going to be splattered across the walls. Then with a single throw, 7 of them just drop dead. And the rest? Well, there seems to be a large impact on morale with these explosions. Sometimes you dont even have to hit anyone. They hear these beasts go off nearby, and that's all for them! FT! Im done!!Another drawback to this game: They took out a lot of the weapons you could get in the original. My favorite was the heavy axe (Or something it was a one-hamded axe, dealing 40c) and they also took out the lucern (Fudge spealling, the pole-hammer) both gone. Replaced now by generic fencing swords and eastern equivalents. The game is still entirely playable, but you just yearn for your tried and true steel buddies of old. Other features of note: You can upgrade and armor recruits at mercenary camps. Each camp has their own nationality and their upgrades only affect that nationality. (Rascist, I know) In cities and Castles/fortresses: You can visit Weapon, Armor, and Horse masters to order "custom" associated gear. There is also a WONDERFUL new adition of the Merchant Guild!! Leave a couple thousand Thaler (money) at the "bank" and let it accrue interest. Theres even more to mention, but if you even managed to get this far in my review, I salute you! If you liked Warband, just stop reading and get Fire and Sword already! You wont regret it!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												When Mount & Blade came out, it was an ambitious project that did not reach its full potential. The first standalone expansion  (Warband) added some key improvements to the formula, but ultimately it felt like a re-release of the first game with just short of enough new content to justify paying full price for it if you already owned Mount & Blade. With Fire & Sword is the breath of... semi-fresh air that the series needed. The essentials of the gameplay remain almost identical (except for the great addition of powerful firearms and some other additions, which force the player to come up with new tactics). However, it is the setting of this game that really sets it apart from the two previous M&B titles.Based on Henryk Sienkiewicz's historical novel "Ogniem i mieczem", the game pushes us back to a period in real world history instead of fiction. We are taken to mid-17th century Eastern Europe, where the once great Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth is facing war with multiple of its neighbouring nations. This is where the facts end, as the player can choose to ally himself/herself with any of the real factions included in the game (the 'Polish Commonwealth', the 'Kingdom of Sweden', the 'Cossack Hetmanate', the 'Muscovite Tsardom' or the 'Crimean Khanate') and alter the course of history. Alternatively, like in Warband, you may choose to form your own kingdom or simply remain neutral throughout the duration of the game.Ultimately, the gameplay of With Fire & Sword is refined to such an extent that it feels like the most well-designed of the first three M&B titles. However, it is still very similar to the previous games and suffers from the same main flaws at the core: lack of significant unique content in terms of story. The cold and calculated nature of the tasks and actions the player is permitted to do in the game may get tedious after a while of playing. If you didn't enjoy M&B, then perhaps you should skip this one unless you really like history. On the other hand, if you enjoyed Mount & Blade then I see no reason why you shouldn't like this game (its unique and unusual setting, which explores a period in history rarely ever mentioned in video games, makes this experience more interesting).

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Singleplayer Grade 7/10 (mainly due to bugs)Multiplayer Grade 8/10 (If you buy this game for multiplayer, remember to check if there are still active players online playing this game)IMPORTANT:1) TRY FREE DEMO BEFORE PURCHASING!2) Mount & Blade Warband is much better and it has mods that bring firearms to the game.Short review: Like mount & blade Warband, but in different setting. If you hate idea of firearms in this kind of game you shouldn't buy this game. The grade is lower than in Warband, due to some problems in gameplay and large amount of gamebraking bugs.Full review:The singleplayer of this game gives you the possibility to lead mercenary warband in the setting of 17th century eastern europe. Like in mount and Blade warband, the experience is generally exciting and unique. Unlike Mount & blade Warband, which is like huge sandbox, this game tries to create what many consider the the Holy Grail of gaming , which is combining story and sandbox gameplay. Unfortunately the developers failed in this in many ways.First problem is that many players didn't care at all about the story and wanted to play sandbox game, but this was difficult due to the fact that unlike in Warband, you can't create your own kingdom. You can't get married either and there are no tournaments. Because of these and some other reasosn he RPG and sandbox elements are lacking compared to Warband.Second problem is that if you follow the story (I played the Black Mace campaign which on my opinion unfortunately wasn't interesting) you will face problems. The first one of those are huge amount of bugs, that force you to load your saved game many times during the campaing. Many of these bugs are related to the fact that the world of the game changes usually independently comapred to the story. Even when these changes don't cause actual bugs, they can seriously hamper the players attempst to progress in the story. I was for example given task to capture certain city from hostile country Poland, but by the time I had army to capture it, neutral country Crimean Kahanate had already taken it. In order to capture the town, my country would have to start war also against them. This would have been almost certain defeat due to getting into war in two fronts.Third problem is the setting. Some people might be scared about the strange setting, but that is not what is the main problem. The problem that the setting causes is that it affects the gameplay negatively. In mount & Blade Warband, the player can both be commander of his/her troops and also be the superhero in shining armour that kills dozens of enemies on his/her own. This is even somewhat historical because armour made medieval knights very difficult to kill. In Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword, half of those filthy peasants :-) that you used to kill without trouble are now armed with firearms, that kill you with one or two shots on hardest difficulty. Even on lower difficulty levels it is difficult to be superhero anymore. The one shot kill firearms also make melee weapons relatively weak, which is a shame, because one of the best things in Mount & Blade series is the melee combat.Despite the severe problems in singleplayer I gave this game grade of 7, because the basic mechanics of Mount & Blade series are still there and they are great.Multiplayer part is good, mainly due to the uniqueness of Mount & blade combat. The reason to not to give 9/10 for multiplayer is that there are no modifications for multiplayer unlike in Warband, and because the gameplay is slightly worse due to what firearms cause to the gameplay.

												Tis a good but nuanced game. I could only recommend it to people who really like Mount & Blade and are interested in Polish history. Game has promised patches that never came, the "Black Mace" story quest (Ukraine/Zhaparozhie) is still broken IIRC haven't done it recently. The game is also incredibly imbalanced and the firearms are the worst of it. The sad part is that it's not the inclusion of the firearms, but rather their mechanics. You can reload a a full-length rifle while galloping on horseback, I'm not even exaggerating sadly. Like I said good but nuanced game. Only buy if you really like M&B and Polish history.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												This game is fantastic. I've put hundreds of hours into it, and I'll likely put hundreds of house more into it. Takes place in the real world in mid-17th century Eastern Europe. There's 5 factions; Muscovite Tsardom (Russia), Sweden, Poland, Crimean Khanate (Crimea, which is a location in the game), and the Cossacks. You'll meet people from these areas as well as Spaniards, Frenchmen, Germans, and even Scotsmen. There are muskets, and because of the time period, they come in a variety of flavours. Home made, matchlock, wheel lock, and Miquelet (flintlock) are the main ones, in order of quality. Accuracy is in short supply of course, but I do believe there are some rifled muskets in the game, however they are VERY expensive, and not something you can give normal soldiers. Only your own character, and heroes.You amass your own Army, there are many different endings, and there are many different ways to fight. Personally I like to position my cavalry to the side, while my infantry takes 10 paces in front of my marksmen to defend them from enemy cavalry, while my own cavalry does the same. If the enemy bowmen/musketmen get too close for my liking, I'll send in my infantry to charge them, make them switch from ranged attack to melee, so that my own musketman can help quell them while they're busy with my infantry and cavalry. Works very well for me so far, as you can tell it's all basically revolving around my musketmen, but the infantry and cavalry certainly have their place. Without one or the other, I would feel vulnerable. You can cavalry if you like, or perhaps just stick with infantry and musketmen, or even exchange the musketmen for bowmen but you best have some DAMN strong bowmen with some DAMN strong bows because as troops come with heavier armour, those arrows quickly start doing less and less damage, however muskets will always do a lot of damage... when the shots hit. Thick shields and thick armour combined can really lessen a musket's effectiveness however.There's lots of quests, lots of cities and towns, lots of different methods to take in order to secure victory, the replay value is VERY MUCH present, and as many battles as I take part in, it never seems to get old. The tutorial is entertaining enough, complete with voice acting, but it's not something that drags out annoyingly long. It puts you in the action quite quickly, and then you're free to go, Eastern Europe is yours to explore! Though there are some muskets that are so accurate you'd think them rifled, there's always bullet drop, so you'll have to learn to compensate for that. It just adds to the gameplay however, which though simple, is difficult to master, and I'd have it no other way. Like Call of Pripyat with Misery mod (and The Armed Zone if you REALLY want to be overloaded with firearm selection), and like Red Orchestra II/Rising Storm, I expect to ultimately end up with 1000+ hours in this game as the years go by. Sure it doesn't look particularly pretty, but there's a unique appeal to it that I've yet to find in any other game or mod. An experience in and of itself.The process of leveling up, improving my various aspects, getting better gear, customizing ther Mercenaries available for hire at Mercenary Camps, training them up from Recruit, to Experienced, to Veteran, to Elite... it's so much fun that I've lost count of how many time I've restarted the game. A clean slate starting at day 1, my current playthrough is over 450 days in-game, over a year's worth, my Army is at a max of about 87-88 troops, however when I put the coin down for Mercenaries with ALL the best equipment I can give them, then train them together with a few of my heroes to work them up to Veterans and Elites, my less than 90 soldiers feels more like 150-200 or more, usually depending on how many muskets the enemy is bringing to the battlefield. If none, it feels like I've got 300 troops, might even be gutsy enough to take on 350 if all they have is bowmen, but that might be reaching a bit too far. All the same, there's such a wide range of armour, melee weapons, bows, muskets, horses, troops, and so on... the variety is amazing. Ultimately though, we all know that muskets would come to rule the battlefields in the 18th and early-mid 19th centuries, so although most of the muskets in the game are primitive matchlocks, it can only be expected that they'd ultimately be superior. That said however... armoured, well trained, and well equipped bowmen vs unarmoured, untrained, and ill-equipped musketmen? I'd put my money on the bowmen any day of the week. You don't pick up a musket and you're suddenly invincible. If you see a hussar barreling at you on horseback with lance couched, as of yet untouched on the battlefield, a single musket ball will likely do little more than♥♥♥♥♥♥him off, you'll want a second one to finish the job, but if he gets you with that lance, musket or no, you're equally dead both ways. Some say that cavalry with muskets is all you need, but cavalry can only use carbines of pistols, and not only that, firing on horseback isn't as accurate as firing on the ground, so not only does fool soldiers with muskets have more accurate firearms that cause more damage, they also have the advantage of firing on the ground. However once they have to be forced to use melee, the shooting stops, and if the enemy is still shooting or firing arrows, then you're at a heavy disadvantage, which is where the infantry comes into play. Troops trained in melee combat, often given better melee weaponry, have them positioned to protect your musketmen, just as pikemen had done before the advent of the bayonet. If the fighting becomes stagnant though, with the musketmen a mere 50m away, sending in volley after volley, order the infantry to charge, get up in their faces so they can't keep their muskets spitting, but keep your men firing lead balls into them. Yes, just like chess, there are many ways to attain victory. Find your own way, your own troops, your own tactics, and take 17th century Eastern Europe for your own! HUZZAH!

												BUTThe reason I don't recommend this game is because it's predecessor (M&B: Warband) is an absolute gem with essentially the exact same graphics and gameplay but for me it just feels.. better. If you haven't tried it then you should go pickup Warband and if you have played Warband then I'm here to warn you that F&S is just a little bit off.I can't quite put my finger on it; perhaps it's the strategical considerations that come into play with the introduction of firearms, or perhaps it simply wasn't balanced quite as well, but either way F&S on the whole is just not as enjoyable to me as Warband. Both are exceptionally unique and fantastic games but I would either buy Warband if you're new to Mount and Blade or stick with Warband if you're a fan of the series.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												I spent 5 years trying to come up with a funny review for this game. I failed. Now, I'm gonna stick with the good ol' boring, wannabe helpful review.I don't have an idea why I didn't reviewed this game for so long but seeing those fresh recruitments (thx to bannerlord I guess), I decided to be helpful to those who consider buying this game as a committed player of the series, started playing Mount and Blade in November 2009 and spent many days&nights playing it since then.Comparison to the previous games; Even tho scenarios to take the throne of some nations (like Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Russia) were added as a unique feature to it's predecessors, Single player was a little... dull. Despite using firearms, siege artillery still wasn't added to the game. There are some features like; ordering a weapon for yourself, changing equipment of the mercenaries from their camps for a price (yeah, they have camps now) etc. but also It didn't have marriage or creating your own kingdom/empire so they took some things out, put some in.Multiplayer on the other hand was quite entertaining, especially clan battles. So just go for it If you want to pvp. Even tho, the era of clans is over, you won't have trouble finding a server if it's not late night or morning. Multiplayer is still not dead! The game isn't demanding and most likely to run smoothly on ancient rigs. (Hello 128 MB Video Card)  Graphics are ok, not great but ok. (Graphics wasn't the MB's strong suit anyways). As for the price, It's cheaper than what it deserves right now.* I give it a 7/10, feels incomplete in so many levels but also doesn't fail to keep you entertained. At the current price, It's worth it.

												YEs! this game has everything that made Warband great plus early era guns and cannons! i put off playing it for a while, because i was worried the guns would be too overpowered and sometimes they can be. you can be mid to late game and be a super high level with tons of health and armor and get murdered by a couple stray bullets, but it's not something that's going to happen a lot. especially if you play smart. i think this game requires much more strategy than Warband. in warband, by the time i've level 40 or so, i can wade into a battle and kill 20-50 people on my own and it's much harder to do that in this one because of how much damage guns can do. you also tend to have more casualties during battle and numbers tend to matter more. it's like they took all the good parts about warband and added to it. more quests, a new world, new factions, more and different weapons (including primitive grenades). beyond all that, the various factions have their own storylines which i did not need, but kind of love. playing as the polish will have some different quests from the swedish which are different from the russians which is different from the crimeans. the addition of the story elements add some believability to the various relations between the factions because you learn why they like the factions they like and hate the factions they hate.if you played warband and like it, you'll most likely enjoy this game too. if you haven't played warband, i recommend getting the mount and blade full collection and playing warband first, then coming to this, because there are some major differences in gameplay. i assure you the addition of guns and bombs adds much more depth and strategy to this game than warband had to it. that's not to say warband was bad or too easy, just that guns make it easier to kill than swords. which we all already knew anyway.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												TL;DR It's a fun game but Mount and blade warband is better.Let me explain. I bought this game on a sale because guns sound a lot more fun and warband was more expensive. So I bought this and the original mount and blade. The problem with this game is that the single player is hard. Like really hard. It's hard earning money, there is no real tutorial to learn you how to start your own empire or join an existing empire etc.My first time playing my men were starving, I had ♥♥♥♥♥♥ weapons and I was fighting bandits in hope that I could pay for my soldiers and food. Eventually my luck ran out and I lost everything. This has been a theme for my experience with the singleplayer. It's fun if you know how to play and earn money without going to tournaments and cheating the system like in warband. So why do I have so many hours on it? Well the multiplayer is awesome. Shooting people with muskets and♥♥♥♥♥♥is a ton of fun. It's a bit like the napoleonic dlc for warband, which is a ton of fun, but more derpy. I guess this is where I conclude my review. This game is fun if you know how to play, the multiplayer is the best part and I've played a lot of it however the singleplayer is somewhat lacking and where the previous games were fun this one is too difficult and time consuming. I've put 20 hours or so into the singleplayer but I just don't get into it.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
UPDATE: As much as I would like to get into this game more its pretty boring compared to Warband. Plus I hate the looks of the clothing and weapons.While Mount and Blade: With Fire & Sword isn't as fun as Warband, it's still pretty awesome. I've read both positive and negative reviews for this game and I can see how it can go either way. I personally enjoy this game, it gives you an entirely new perspective on the world forcing the player to adapt to a new environment very quickly. I find making enemies much easier in With Fire & Sword than it was in Warband, so you need to watch what you do or you could find yourself alone against an army.Mount and Blade: With Fire & Sword is very similar to Warband only in a different era (The 17th Century to be exact). Here's my breakdown of WFaS:PROS+ Includes 21 Steam Achievements (Some more challenging to get than others)+ Requirements are low allowing this game to be played on almost every computer+ All Castles & Fortresses have Taverns (Unlike in Warband it was just the towns)+ Ability to chat with the Mayor/Elders directly from the town menu (Unlike in Warband you had to find them yourself)+ Ability to make a wagon fort (Allows for a better defense perimeter in Battles, but does not necessarily give you an avantage)CONS- No Steam Trading Cards- Larger quantity of Bandits/Looters/Enemies than in WarbandWHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? WITH FIRE AND SWORD! (BUY THIS GAME)My Rating: 9/10 (Recommended)

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
Pros:+Firearms+Grenades+Additional siege options (sneak through town, blow up wall, poison water supply)+Campaigns+More town/empire management+Real map locations+Can trade in castles (was not able to in Warband)+Bank/debt system (however simple it might be)+Can place orders on the best equipment from various venders (new feature)Neutral:~New siege system. Multiple ladders instead of one. Good if you are an attacker, bad if you are defender. ~Gameplay. Overpowered bullet damage forces you to keep your distance and player smarter. Cons:-HORRIBLE SIEGE AI. ABSOLUTELY ATROCIOUS. Half the time your troops or the enemy is just standing there, doing absolutely NOTHING or they keep switching their weapons back and forth, whilst doing nothing. -Bugs. CTD bugs after tabbing out, finishing a battle, or just traversing the map sometimes. 'Line error' messages and more bugs sometimes after battles and quest completions. And then you can also shoot someone and the bullet will go behind and not do any damage. Extremely annoying.-Campaign intructions are vague and hard to figure out. You will end up using google to complete missions. I guarantee it. -Tax revenue from towns is no longer automatic. You have to visit your town to collect.Overall, it is a step down from Warband. Sure, you can say "but guns, so cool, much wow. pew pew gg" but these new additions do NOT make up for the sloppy AI and the bugs. The "RAAHH CHARGE!!!! I'LL KILL 50 OF YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S!!" feeling at the beginning of every battle is not the same as it is in Warband, there's more of a risk to go in balls deep forcing you to stay back in every battle.TL;DR - Do not buy this game if you are looking to get into the Mount & Blade series, buy Warband instead.. Vanilla (unmodded) Warband offers a similar experience but with less of the hassle. Modded Warbands offers a superior experience, and it has a wide array of mods in comparison.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Its actually challenging! Instead of just spamming rhodoks or nords you actually have to think here. Musketeers are vital to a healthy strong army, but are terrible in combat, infantry is high damage but not very hardy and calvary is EXTREMELY EXSPENSIVE but hold a raw power unseen by any force on earth besides the German Blitzkrieg, but be warned, these arent the Swadian tanks weve come to love, charging a musketeer wall head on is a mistake and you WILL lose men! constantly refresh your reserves. As always make sure to keep your factions kept within your army to one or two as desertion is common. Be warned, you are no longer the god wielding death and mayhem with your heavy armor and two handed weapons as seen in warband, shaking off all but the most powerful blows, in this game you are very, very vulnerable early game and even late game you are still able of being beaten. Armor and weapons are exspensive and money can be hard to come by, COMPLETE FAVORS TO GET MEN. PERIOD. GET DAT TOWN RELATION STAT AS HIGH AS A KITE BECAUSE WITOUT IT YOUR ARMY WILL DWINDLE! AND IF YOU RUN INTO DESERTERS EARLY GAME PAY THEM OFF! THESE ARE NOT THE IDIOTIC NORD AXEMEN THAT YOU CAN RIDE AROUND AND SABRE ONE BY ONE, THESE ARE MEN WITH MUSKETS AND CALVARY OF THEIR OWN THAT CAN AND WILL 1 HIT KILL YOU, YOUR FOLLOWERS, AND EVERY SINGLE ONE OF YOUR MEN. MY FIRST PLAYTHROUGH I HAD 20 SCYTHE WIELDERS AND RAN INTO 6 WINGED HUSSARS. NEEDLESS TO SAY I WAS CAPTURED AND MY ARMY DECIMATED. GREAT GAME

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												Here's the thing - if you're looking for the best mount & blade to buy and can only afford one of them, this is, sadly, not the choice to make. I love this game but Warband is the superior one, although this one has guns for the campaign, the gameplay is better and warband and there's just not anything new here. I enjoy both of the games, but this game does lack in comparison. Now is it a bad game? Hell no. I love using a two-handed claymore one minute and switching to a pistol for the next wave of enemies, and having a group of 100 men with nearly all of them using muskets is so satisfying when you can watch them shoot down the entire enemy group. If you can afford both mount and blades grab both of them, and while you'll throw more hours into the other, you'll get a great amount of game time and fun from this one as well to make your purchase worth it. Just wait for a sell first.

												okay my review:Maps 5.5/10.0Well you might ask me: why so low score? just because they didnt make castles historically accurate, and just a few unique buildings, while the eastern europe was filled of them. Example: my country's capital Vilna (Lithuanian spelling: Vilnius) had a river getting into two pieces, a very steep hill with a great tower on top and walls surrounding. the tower on hill is even today staying there. you could google it too. Trakai, that village nearby, was no worse, it had huge great fort in a island which was in a huge lake, altho what i've seen was a random village with a few houses ingame. The map could've been more accurate.Combat + Units 8.0/10.0The game, has great combat, altho sometimes AI gets easily stuck or it forgets to fight and other funny buggy things. sometimes they even bug out so hard, but still its good.But the units, you could've make a bigger variety of them, because i am pretty sure there was not a lack of unit kinds there. I like the ones that you made, but some are little inaccurate.Storylines + Quests 7.5/10.0The Quests from cities are a little boring: if you do much of them, they repeat quickly...Storylines are good, but sometimes buggy.Factions 9.5/10Well they're great, but it would've been more amazing if we wouldve had prussia, ottomans, austrians too!Overall calculated rating of these things from me is 7.625/10.000

number of helpful: 24 of 41 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												This is a mod of the original version of Mount & Blade. The primary focus of this mod is the singleplayer campaign revolving around the formation of the Moscovite Tsardom of Russia, the Swedish Deluge into Poland, and the Crimean Khanate Incursion into Kiev; this is the modern day area of Eastern Sweden, Poland, Ukraine, and Western Russia. The big gameplay change is the inclusion of firearms; however since this is based on the original Mount & Blade, the Player will automatically lose the battle if his character is knocked out. With the inclusion of volley fire firearms, the player character can be knocked out with a single bullet, causing the gameplay to suffer greatly. The second large addition to this mod is 3 unique questlines revolving around the kingdoms of Poland, Cossack Ukraine, and Moscovite Russia. However, the questlines are near impossible to complete without a guide, are buggy, and poorly translated.With the singleplayer losing most of its charm with combat being against the player's favor, and the quests being difficult, requiring guides, buggy, AND uninteresting, I cannot recommend this game.The multiplayer is an interesting take, but the Napoleonic Wars mod for Warband handles firearms much better. I recommend M&B: Warband over this game. Free Warband mods are vastly better than this one.

number of helpful: 35 of 62 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Buy Warband instead. The difficulty between this game and Warband has been increased greatly, which isn't a bad thing. Once you got a hang of Warband the AI got fairly easy. Unfortunately success in this game is not only greatly more difficult, especially at the lower levels, but often your success in matters are not only random, but often the odds of missions you are given are literally impossible.If the only issue was difficulty it'd not be a problem. But mission scaling is horrendously broken. If you take a mission, especially at the lower levels, you have typically less than a fifty percent chance of finishing it. I would say the game is just too difficult, but I've nearly mastered Warband and I can't play this one for more than a few minutes without either losing and getting captured, or save scumming.

number of helpful: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 27
												Tl&dr: my recommendations for M&B variants are as follows:1. Viking Conquest Reforged2. Floris mod3. Warband4. Any mod you can find, but you can expect some crashes and bugs in some5. With fire and sword6. Blood and Gold: Carribean! (only for a 5 minutes laugh)I assume this M&B version wanted to put the player in a position closer to an army general than the original Warband, but fails to do even that through its own fault. This is why (comparing to Warband):- no more character attributes design at start of the game. You start with the same point in all attributes and can distribute only a few. You will be a poor fighter, poor trader with a slightly above average IQ; no other choice.- since the discovery of fire (a.k.a. muskets) any fight can end abruptly if some mediocre rifleman gets lucky and lands a head shot from across the map, no matter how many hit points you have or what head gear you use; but to be honest, this can be avoided 99.99% of the times if you get a horse and run around in circles like a crazy chicken. In short, if you run around buck naked you survive, if you stand still in the best armor in the game, you die.- although the game almost forces you into a command position, the battle map size doesn't really give you this feeling. Half the times, after you give a few commands and your men start to move into position, the enemy cavalry is already close and charging, turning what should be a clean line-infantry battle into a total mess of men and horses.- adding to the above point is the battle size limiter to 150, which makes you feel like you are the leader of an oversized gang, rather than some wannabe Napoleon. There are tools to increase this size to 1000, but, considering the small maps, having 1000 men fighting is more of a lottery than some tactical or strategic combat.- Warband had a questionable AI at best in siege battles, but this one made the step forward. The best result I had against this terrible AI was at a siege 60 attackers vs. 180 defenders. Attackers won with 1 wounded and 1 dead.- speaking of AI, do not expect any challenges on the global map either. No matter what you do, you can't be outsmarted, the only way to lose anything is through brute force, when you are seriously outnumbered.- story-line quests are bugged; almost all of them. The only one that works without constantly saving because of the fear of the bugs is the Polish one. However, it has some interesting ways to make the game challenging. One moment you have half of the map, the next half of your cities belong to the enemy without any battles fought or any warnings. Why? Because you talked to some guy and asked him what's wrong. Thank you.- no more tournaments, lots of quests from Warband removed- troop upgrade trees are lacking imagination to say the least- money from fiefs are not sent to you automatically forcing you to make a tour every now and then to collect your taxesOverall, a M&B with less interesting combat, but in which you can trade and become a tax collector.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Props to my good friend RedAlpha for giving me this games as a Christmas gift. Thanks alot, buddy. Fire & Sword, as a standalone expansion to Warband, is almost mechanically identical to it's relative game and has everything from it that makes it good, but there are tweaks and alterations that set it apart from the game enough to justify it as it's own separate title. Not only changing the weapons that the skills constitute and the armor and apparel to go with the new, much more advanced and recent setting than Warband, but to go with that, they added guns and grenades (Hence 'Fire and Sword'.) which is my favorite selling point in this game, because of this, they changed the ranged infantry from Archers to Marksmen, whom you can command to form rows thanks to the new additions to the order-giving system this game has. However, Fire & Sword also shares the two infamous gripes I have with Warband: Frustration with regards to difficulty, and as mentioned in the Warband review, letting a snail win a race to you while you're -riding a horse.- Oh well, just like Warband, this gets a 9/10, an impressive.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												This game is probaly the best sword fighting game I have ever played :D It's amazingly addictive and keeps you entertained for hours...But the thing is, it was originally a DLC so it's not that big a game. But that doesen't mean it's only has 1 level. It has 2 modes: castle seige and battle mode. (+ Campaign mode).In both battle mode and castle siege you only have one life, which immediatly rises the tension.The campaign mode is good and fun, but i prefer the other game modes. The online exprience has some different maps and it is modable (Is that a word)?but the other players.. My god they are annoying.So say you want some good old swordfighting action, yeah? You want them to fully block, and attacklike a proper duel, yes? But the thing is, the other players think that doing that is bullsh*t and spin around in circles while mashing left click is a good way to win a fight. Just saying.Overall Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword is a great game but however has some issuses. (I forgot to mention that the graphics aren't that good, but that doesn't ruin the experience at all).The game has a simple to learn but hard to master combat system. It's very simallar to Chivalry Medival Warfare.In other words, BUY THE GAME!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I'm up in the air with yes and no. It is not as good as Warband, but it's fun. It's got optional story, which is nice, and guns and horses and swords, which are all nice, (oh, and GRENADES!) but it has its fair share of problems. You can't set up your custom kingdom, you can only usurp existing ones. Bad. You can die (yes, that matters a lot!), which is not supposed to happen in M&B, and some of the storylines are just plain silly. Looking at The Deluge and Black Mace! False Dmitri is probably the best one. Speaking of which, this game is considerably more linear than the others, which is why it is out of the loop. Mount&Blade is supposed to be sandbox open-world blah blah. Also, you can't go home and become a family man here. You don't have that option anymore. So, go back to Warband for the moment, and wait until Bannerlord to -see if it is any good-. EDIT: Bannerlord will be the best game of all time. Be a family man.Anyway, returning to this, guns! Why not? The other best part is that if you hire a mercenary army, you can customise their uniforms. 11/10, would make morion-toting Crusader army again.

content:
Posted: January 4
												-Started campaign-Became a trader and made some money-Hired mercanaries and began adventuring in the north-Did a couple quests for the muscovite tsardom-Found an old man in a village who gave me a golden cross and pistol-Decided to not pay attention to what the man said and went to do more quests for the tsardom-Delievered a horse to the tsar-About to be vassalized for bringing a horse to him when he sees the cross-Got thrown in jail-Escaped jail and fled to poland-Found a claiment to the tsardom who decided to help me overthrow the tsardom-Used the cross and claimed i was the real heir to the tsardom to turn the entire army against the tsar-Overthrew the tsar and betrayed the claiment who helped me-Became the new tsar and led the muscovite tsardom to glory.10/10 would overthrow the muscovite tsardom again.Seriously though this game is pretty good, not as good IMO as warband but its up there, wouldnt suggest getting this if you want to just join a kingdom and take over the world as the vassalize system feels slightly broken (Tried to get vassalized once by sweden got the king to 80 opinion of me and had fought so many battles against his enemies yet he wouldnt vassalize me at all) however sieges are pretty fun and there are more options than in warband for sieges such as blowing a hole in a wall. Outside of sieges combat is really fun and requires you to use a strategy instead of just charging all the time like most would in warband, however it does have alot of glitchs from what i can see and IMO is not as well done as warband is however one thing this game has over warband is story quests, three of them infact one for the muscovites, one for the polish, and one for the cossacks, they are pretty fun and enjoyable decent length to. 7/10 great game if you like 1600's combat and want to play a mount and blade game that has a "main story" element and don't mind the fact the game feels a little unfinished in some areas

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												A good game. Though it isn't as good as Mount and Blade: Warband, it is still awesome in its own way.Pros: Guns - guns are OP. Sure, they take a long time to reload, but they have power and can wipe out whole armies.Actual trading - assessing local prices actually means something and you can make lots of money by doing it. Also, you get to form your own caravans, which is awsome and makes you very rich if you do it right.Banks and Guilds -you get to deposit money in banks and gain interest on that. You can also take loans as well. There are special guilds which can sell you special armor and weapons. Though expensive, they are very cool and can provide you with some cool stuff.Useful Castles - sounds weird, I know, but now every fortress or castle has a tavern and a marketplace. Unlike the Warband castles, which were basically just strongholds, the WF&S castles allow you to sell stuff, access the tavern, and talk to a mayor for quests. Interesting story-based quests  - there are special series of story-based quests for the Poles, the Russians, and the Cossacks. These stories are well-done and are quite interesting, giving you some history lessons while at the same time letting you campaign and battle Mount and Blade style.Grenades  - sure, they're almost always inefficient and usually not worth the steep price, but they are freaking GRENADES. IN MOUNT AND BLADE!!!!Cons - Bugs and Glitches - the developers moved on before the game was fully fixed, which is a huge shame. Though the game is mostly smooth and most problems have been dealt with, you may experience some graphical glitches here and there. At the worst, you will have a bug that wiill ruin your game. For example, a faction leader will be defeated in battle and never reappear, or the story-based quests will break and you'll be forever stuck on one part. Hopefully, you won't have these, but you've been warned.Lack of variety - in Warband, all the factions were truly unique, with obvious strengths and weaknesses. In WF&S, all the factions seem the same. Aside from appearances and some strengths (Poles= cavalry. Swedes = infantry), the factions don't have enough variety to make they feel truly unique in battle. At the end of the day, they are all essentially the same.No Story for Crimeans and Swedes - while the Russians, Poles, and Cossacks have story-based quests, the Crimeans and Swedes have none, which is a shameMap is Bland - in Warband, you have a desert, a steppe, a tundra, a mountain range, and a plains region. These added variety to the game and made the different areas unique. In WF&S, the entire map is flat, with just rivers and a few patches of forest. Woop-ee. Overall, don't let the cons prevent you from buying the game. It is a very fun and exciting experience which all Mount and Blade fans should have.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword, with regards to how much I like it, and how much I don't, is quite a hard game to review. Overall it feals a lot like Mount and Blade, which is hardly suprising, but then it feels more advanced with the guns, almost like Napoleonic Wars DLC for Warband. Graphically i don't think Fire and Sword is really an inmprovement. Personally i don't think it looks very good, but let's be honest, that is never what Mount and Blade was about. If it was, they failed every time. The playstyle of the game is very much the same as all other games, with the same idea behind blocking and attacking n melee, and shooting. This is set in the early era of the invention of guns, i don't know for certain but maybe early 1700's? Either way, the uniforms for the soldiers look very old, and the guns are NOT very accurate. They also feel very 'light' and a bit too easy to aim, in comparison to that of Napoleonic Wars.The campaign is 'good'. That is about all i can say for it. It is much like the other games of it's type. Overpriced equipment, limits on army size and plenty of fetch and carry missions, and still no luck with marrying into a wealthy family. I think once you have played any Mount and Blade campaign, you have played them all. I can't think of much more to review in this game, maybe because there is nothing else. Overall, i don't like the time era very much which has turned me away from the game. I prefer the Napoleonic Wars by far. Other than that, death and melee still looks stupidly unrealistic, gunshots sound like...anything but gunshots, and the music is quite bad. Despite all this, i cannot say i don't like the game. Mount and Blade are good at making addictive games that are quite bad in comparison to other games, yet still very good. I know all that made sense, but i feel better for getting that out. 8/10. Graphics and the era ruined it for me more than anything, but i do like it.

												Amazing game, it captures the steppe/eastern style of warfare perfectly in the 17th century. I love this game and have enjoy it immensely a thousands times more than Warband. The line battles in Napoleonic Wars don't even match up to this game. TaleWorlds Entertainment is ripping themselves off by offering this standalone for 10$. I do not lie when I say if I could do it all over again, I would have purchased this at full price, not on sale and never picked up Warband. Its obvious more people like Warband because it's medieval theme, but for people like me, Fire and Sword is a little trip to gamer's heaven. While the loyal fanbase is moving on to Bannerlord, I'll still be on my little island, riding my war horse, bow in hand, leading Khan styled hoards, charging straight for an army of Polish Winged Hussars, while arquebus and wheelock muskets can be heard in the distance.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Fire & Sword is like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little brother of Warband. The Singleplayer is like watching paint dry even with the additons of should be badass items like grenades. The range of clothing and weapons is dissapointing unless you want to wear the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ top in various sizes and colours all game. The game is not worth buying just for singleplayer. The only thing that comes close to saving this game is the commander game variant in Multiplayer out of my 120 odd hours about 100 of it was spent in that gamemode, it had a better feel to it than even the commander mode in NW. The smaller squad sizes and abiltiy to choose your troops specifically, gives the gamemode a much more tactical feel and when you loose a man, it hurts, it would actually sadden me when one of my 6 childeren took a bullet to the head.I will still reccomend the game because of this one gamemode, without it the game wouldnt be worth it. Even with the gamemode I would wait for a sale of the game as paying full price for it is as stupid as the game itself.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												First of all I would recommend this game for anyone who likes sandbox games ( for the single player mode ). One reason this game is so unique is because it has a different style of musket fighting than in the other mount and blade mods. The game gives you a sense of individuality in multiplayer, in which there is no sandbox you just battle with other people. In the other mount and blade mods and other games like those, you fight in groups so you are more of a body of men than a single soldier. In the multiplayer almost everyone moves at their own free will, like an irregular. So being a musketeer means more of you by yourself than you in a battalion of infantry. But it also allows other things, imagine a knight with a gun. This game is very fun but the multiplayer takes a while to master especially since there are a lot of hackers on some of the servers so PRACTICE!!! But other than that this game is very wide spread so it covers a lot of fields so this game is definitely one of my favorites.

content:
Posted: January 21
												Ever sense I had the pleasure of getting M&B warband ive been a huge huge huge fan of the series. Clocking in nearly 100 hours in almost no time it was easy to get lost into this medival world. Generally text bases rpg's would steer me away but not the m&b series. The combat is just sooo perfect easy to learn and soooo difficult to master. Multiplayer is tense and rewarding as you see yourself climb the leaderboards the more you play. The story mode is amazing allowing you to make a character and a story completely your own. It is difficult for new players but if you press on you will not be dissapointed. You can literally be and do anything you want. Wanna be a trader of goods make profit by selling various goods from food to silk. Maybe join a faction and pledge your allegiance to it. Do you wanna say ♥♥♥♥ that and start your own empire from the ground up to take over the entire continent. YOU CAN! its an amazing game and the new guns add another layer of difficulty and tension this is a must own so if you dont own a M&B game GET ONE DAMNIT. 10/10 who needs a life anyway when you can start your medival empire.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												WF&S is basicly a mod for M&B: Warband, sacrificing some of Warband features for actual historical background.If you played Warband, you know what to expect. If you haven't - M&B is a sandbox game. You are being thrown into a pretty big map, full of villages and cities belonging to one of five factions. And then... well, you tell me. You want to become a bandit, rob caravans and burn villages? Why not? Want to be a vigilante, taking down bandits and doing small jobs for the lords? Why wait? How about joining the faction, gaining fiefs, and taking over hostile factions? Go on. Or maybe... create your own faction, and become a king? Your call. Or you can always be a merchant. Still a good idea if you enjoy it. This applies both for warband and With fire and Sword.Factions in WF&S are Polish Commonweatlh (with their extraordinary cavalery), Kingdoms of Sweden and Russia, Cossacs and Tatars. Each faction has it's strong and weak sides, as well as it's unique units. Speaking of units, i have to say that I'm  disappointed. not by the numbers - there are plenty of them, but upgrades.... most of the units can only be upgraded to veteran/elite status. Even village recruits can be upgraded maximally to Mercenary status. Which means - obtaining unique faction units is really hard.A word about equipment. Crossbows were removed, instead, you get muskets and pistols. Pretty good and deadly weapons, if you know how to use them. Of course, they need bullets. Luckily, they refill after each battle. Weird enough, granades (yep, there are explosives. Quite powerfull, yet, quite pricy) don't refill. So if you buy pack of 3, use one - next battle you'll have 2. Quite annoying, isn't it? To sum up, if you enjoyed Warband, but got a bit bored with Swandians and other Nords, and want to try something new, but not THAT new, try WF&S.P.S: Just realised that it's just like Napoleonic wars, if it were abit more to the east, and contained single-player

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												It feels like they shoved the Original Mount & Blade forward into time into the gunpowder age. While the guns can almost always kill someone on the first try, the trick is trying to not miss, as the gun takes a good deal of time to reload. Also, most armors with a defense of +10 or higher are expensive and harder to obtain, making it vital to avoid being shot at. The implementation of bar fights, caravan hiring system and diseases really adds into the game that I feel like the original should have had. Addicting and highly enjoyable.

												Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword is an excelent medeval RPG with a hint of strategy. content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I have the original M&B (not Warband), so I have only that to compare it to, but this is probably NOT the first M&B game you should get.   That said, it's a fantastic game, with a few quirks.Best point:  Guns.  They make every battle more tense and unpredictable, because it only takes a stray bullet or two to put you out of comission fast.  While in the old M&B I would just charge in and kick♥♥♥♥♥(once I got to a certain level) even against ridiculous odds, in this one I've actually found myself strategizing, having the marksmen follow me, coming in slowly.  Aside from guns, money and supplies seem a little more plentiful and goods more fairly priced, which means I'm not always worrying whether or not I'm going to have the funds/food to pay/feed the troops.Worst point:  Glitchy main story quests.  I had to restart after several hours of play, just because of a buggy quest that would not allow me to join a faction.  Not saying it will happen to you, but it certainly dampened my enthusiasm, at least initially.  Also, the tutorial is still too basic, and doesn't explain how or why to join your faction.Bottom line:  If you only get one M&B game, it should probably be Warband (or the original, if it's on sale).  But I play this more than the original now.Note:  Have not ventured into multiplayer yet, but that's not really why I play M&B...

content:
Posted: March 21, 2013
												Beware, this game is shockingly addictive! What starts as a simple, open world RPG with no clear goals or aims turns into a personalized intricate story. My character started as a simple merchant of the Cossacks and soon became a powerful political figure with an impressive army, though with the main goal of ensuring the nation's survival through peace. This game is more historical than the others, though only loosely,  and more visually detailed. The combat system is also better than the others as are much of the other aspects of the game: trading, questing, commanding, etc. The setting of this game is also more advanced, 1700's ish as there are wheellock and matchlock firearms. This game and the other Mount and Blade games are very noteworthy and worth buying on a good sale.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												It's a Mount and Blade game. Need I saw more? This entire series is a masterpiece. Great story, amazing gameplay, easy to learn - hard to master. Almost everything in this game is perfect. I prefer the 1600s setting over Napoleonic Wars. But like other great games - it's only good because the positives overlay the negatives. By god, there's a lot of them.- Crashes: The game crashes often. It's not really a graphics issue, it happens when interacting with an NPC. Even still, without crashing, clicking dialouge options often drops FPS waay low.- Hit Detection: Guns are the main selling point of this game. And they suck. More often than not, bullets go straight through enemies. Trying to hit anything below the abdomen is a surefire miss.- Siege: Sieges 'glitch" out a lot. Once you've pushed pass the wall, you head down to engage the enemy... and there's an invisible wall! The AI just sits back behind this wall - none of your soldiers can hit them, they don't charge, and you can only use what's left of bullets/arrows to take them out. Then retreat, loose morale and have your soldiers suck even more.- AI: They can be stupid sometimes. AI is hard to program - I don't blame 'em.- Music: The music is buggy as hell and likes to-o r-r-r-re-n-n-ot-t-tesic-c-ch is an-n-n-nin-ng as h-e-e-e-ell. (to repeat notes which is annoying as hell)Don't let these cons fool you - this game is amazing. However, some players may get annoyed by these glitches, so be cautious

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Despite what people may say.. I personally think it's really good. Some of the Pros is that they have firearms. Outfits look really nice, HUGE map, and have a few story modes you can partake in (I believe it's Sweden, Russia, Commonwealth, and Crimea). Plus you can actually feel like you're in a line and if you know the commands.. Can win a battle in a single volley. Just as Carolus Rex, I was outnumbed in this battle against Russians. -4 Battle advantage. Didn't look promising for me. But I had a strong musket infantry line. And as Cavalry charged, most went down. And then the infantry came. Took out a large portion of them in two volleys. Now there is cons.. You can't create your own kingdom. Apparently the economics are bad(I haven't noticed, looks the same to me), can't recruit from villages(as far as I can tell), the huge map makes you look like an ant. So if you zoom out, you're gonna lose yourself. Or where you're trying to find. Though overall, I love the game. Very fun and unlike the Custom Battles for Napoleonic Wars of M&B, the AI can actually shoot their guns. The rating I give is Recommend and a 7/10. I think they could've done more to Fire and Sword. But it's still a good game. Don't buy into the negative "The economy is ♥♥♥♥♥♥" or "Glitches everywhere". Because I haven't found a single glitch yet. Or at least one I haven't noticed.EDIT - After playing for WAY more, I'll edit the review some more. The Story modes are The Polish Commonwealth, Russia, and The Cossaks. And you can technically "own" a kingdom. You just can't name it, or be for one paticular side. The fief you capture will be called the land you took it from with "Rebels" at the end. (For example, if you conquered Warsaw, it would be "The Polish Commonwealth(Rebels)". Though, unfortunately, you can't do anything with it besides own having it for yourself. Regardless, it's still very fun.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Honestly, this is my favorite game and in WFAS it just gets better. Not Only are you getting a hands on experience about a certain period in time, but you also get to make your own character, build you own army however you please, and become a lord of your own nation. If that doesn't suit you, you can become in kind to a bandit and raid "innocent" villages and reap to rewards. Or you may wish to be a merchant, learn the arts of trade, what sells for good where and how to make money quick. Feeling lonely playing by yourself? You can play online with friends and pplay through different scenarios. Ever wanted to besiege a castle, or fight alongside up to 200 men? you ccan do all that here in a quick battle, too. The point is, this game is great in most fields and live up to more than its expectations. Mount & Blade in general is a great series and WFAS keeps the trend goiing. 10/10. Besides graphics, I believe this is one of the best games and you will not be dissapointed by getting it. GG no re. Hope to see you online soon!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												The game is so good, I literaly bought it again on Steam, only so I can give it a positive review. With Fire and Sword is a standalone thrid party created Expansion to the Mount & Blade. It put's the game into the real 17th century Europe, and does provide player with an optional story mode, and tons and tons of new features and usage eases. After you get used to playing with Fire and Sword, the Warband itself will just feel empty, and limited. The game however requires a bit of mindset changing if you are a Warband fan already, since 17th century armies were marginally different from the villager raised armies of Calradia. The multiplayer game also provides players with slightly altered combat system (Difference can be felt only by the very dedicated players), that is the matter of taste. I persoanlly like the way combat works in Wfas more than WB, but I do understand that some people my like the feel of WB more than Wfas. Generally the game is worth your money, especially now that it is on sale. I have spent more than  1000 hours in the game over the last 4 years I have it. (Some of the features that were added to this game : - Optional Story lines- More siege possibilites- Better siege AI navigation- Training soldiers in castles and towns- A LOT of new buildings to build in your towns- Buildings now also require hiring people to operate them- Being able to choose equipment for some of your troops- Ability to talk with Guild master / Village chief without finding them in city- Building provisoric defenses to help you on field batte (wagon fort)and many, many other minor changes like loaning money, sending NPC's to academies, tavern brawls, sending merchant caravans etc.)The game however does not feature : - Marriages- Tournaments- Training camps (They serve different purpose now)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword is a game many fans don't view in a positive light, and while I cant say exactly why, I can make a few guesses. The biggest to me is probably the introduction of firearms into Mount and Blade, its pretty powerful. early on, and I myself never had any problems just riding into huge battles alone on horseback just to shot dead most enemies before finishing off any stragglers. That being said I feel like it is also missing some of the broader features of Warband, thus losing some of the variation in gameplay. I have not spent as much time with the game, on or off Steam as I have with the other two Mount and Blade games so I don't have as much experience with Mount and Blade with Fire and Sword. That being said, I myself Still really like the game and recommend Mount and Blade fans try it.

This game is amazing, shows big and important history of eastern europe for example Swedish deluge(1655-1660), defense of Czestochowa(1655) or Bohdan Khmelnytsky uprising(1648-1657) and story about False Dimitry.(refers to various pretenders to the Russian throne during the Time of Troubles (1598-1613). Russian Tsar Vasily IV Shuysky gave tribute to Polish King Zygmunt III Waza.(1611) A lot of historical thread in one game. MAKE POLAND GREAT AGAIN!~Enjoy 8/10.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												This is one of the best games I've ever played. The very first time I played was around 4 years after it was released, at the time I played the demo just to check if it's worth it. The demo was almost nothing and you didn't have too much time to play but I did buy it because I wanted to see what I could do next.I've played this game for a long while, about 4 years now, when I started really enjoying it. It is an old game, yes, but it's worth every dollar I spent on it. This game might not be the most epic game in the world but it's still fun to just go around, completing missions, getting an army and getting to rule land. The game has multiplayer as well, which makes it even more fun. Sadly not a lot of people play Fire&Sword.I don't have too much to say about this game. It's just really fun and I'm sure some will really get into it. I've never seen any bugs and glitches in this game. This game runs smoothly with nothing bad happening, though it might crash rarely, but it's no problem if you save your game from time to time.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2011
												I'm still adamant this game will be awesome, so don't pass judgement just yet. They do a lot of bugfixing in this game, they just have a bit of a slow development cycle. They still need to fix achievements, as they don't appear.The game strikes me more as a 'P2P Mod' than a typical expansion. It also appears to compound the problems of the last game, namly starting out, since 7 bandits with guns are much more likely to take out the lone wanderer than 7 bandits in previous games. However, all the open-endedness is still there, now in some kind of maybe Russian land but now with added featuers like banks and most importantly: guns. For all you people who read the last review and needed guns, but were too stupid to figure out how to install a mod: get this. If you like Mount&Blade and can deal with the above problems: get this. If you havn't really tried the series and want to play: go get Warband. Bugs, guns, fun.

												So i have noticed most people have been comparing With Fire and Sword to Warband. Warband is good in that it has tons of mods to make the game more and more interesting. Warband does allow you to just be a factionless bandit hunter, and WFaS its very limited.  But just build your way up by trading goods between factions, earn good money, buy mercenaries for your army, pick a faction and join them, or be gutsy and take on a faction by yourself. content:
Posted: August 25, 2011
												Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword is just not as good as Warband but will still have you playing for hours when you get into it.WFaS made by a polish company (as far as i can remember) set in the 15th to 17th century adds guns to madness that is 'MaB' but personally i still prefer the Swords and combat rather than ranged weapons.The map personally is not great but it is only a map, everything else is just the same as it was in Warband. Just a storyline to go with the action, new factions based on true history and plenty of men to boot.This Warband focuses less on allowing you to create your own faction and more or less forces you to become a Vassal. Again nothing wrong with that, it's just very unrewarding claiming your own kingdom so i tend to avoid it.Overall, everything is the same you just may not like it as much but it is still woth the money easily and the online also remains with guns helping increase the diversity of troops.I grant this a solid 8.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2011
												I'm still adamant this game will be awesome, so don't pass judgement just yet. They do a lot of bugfixing in this game, they just have a bit of a slow development cycle. They still need to fix achievements, as they don't appear.The game strikes me more as a 'P2P Mod' than a typical expansion. It also appears to compound the problems of the last game, namly starting out, since 7 bandits with guns are much more likely to take out the lone wanderer than 7 bandits in previous games. However, all the open-endedness is still there, now in some kind of maybe Russian land but now with added featuers like banks and most importantly: guns. For all you people who read the last review and needed guns, but were too stupid to figure out how to install a mod: get this. If you like Mount&Blade and can deal with the above problems: get this. If you havn't really tried the series and want to play: go get Warband. Bugs, guns, fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												So i have noticed most people have been comparing With Fire and Sword to Warband. Warband is good in that it has tons of mods to make the game more and more interesting. However With Fire and Sword the history in the singleplayer is good (not saying its perfect). The gameplay is good. The graphics, to me, Mount and blade wouldnt be mount and blade without the not great graphics. They're decent graphics though and i like it that way. Warband does allow you to just be a factionless bandit hunter, and WFaS its very limited.  But just build your way up by trading goods between factions, earn good money, buy mercenaries for your army, pick a faction and join them, or be gutsy and take on a faction by yourself. (i dont play with cheats).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												I have to say, I have only played the same old games all the time. Never wanted to venture away from my comfort zone. But this game kinda just grabbed my attention. Yes the grapics are old but the game play is fantastic. Only problem is, if you have no ranged or cav and you are vs cav, prepare to be kited and destroyed i did 1v20 at level 1. They enemy had no ranged weapons so I just rode my horse around in a circle poping off pistol rounds until people would route. I would go after then slice them and repeat. Though when you get into big battles you better know how to issuse to correct commands If not it will cost you the game I say 9/10.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Nothing like Mount & Blade: Warband in terms of how good it is but it still is decent. Its factions aren't made up and the campaign map is of Eastern Europe. The multiplayer is sort of like Native Mount & Blade and Napoleonic Wars mashed together but not perfect. It seems to be one of those games that you might have to give it time for it to warm on you, otherwise it won't at all.I don't mind it, it has some decent multiplayer modes which make it unique and the other game modes aren't that bad. I wouldn't say this game to be good or bad but okay.6/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Mount & Blade: With Fire & Sword It is a good game and i recommend this for all. My computer is complete♥♥♥♥♥♥and i can run this amazing game really smoothly and my computer isnt even a gaming computer anyways.heres the good about this game: the fighting in this game is really good and it is really fun to play with friends to have a good laugh with and team up agains other players you can customize your character Male/Female and make them look how ever you would like. There are a couple of game modes you can play like survival, Teamdeath match, Deathmatch and so on. Theres even a campaign so if you dont feel like playing with other players you can go on there or in private match to play by your self.The bad: The shooting in this game is kind of hard you have to aim in a certain area to shoot someone in the head, leg, chest etc. if you are on a horse and your weapon is a  spear or sword you have to aim in a certain way as well to kill them easy. If you are on foot and about to fight someone and they have a sword and you have a spear it is hard to attack back because the sword is quicker than the spear AND YES there is weight heavy armor with a broad sword or a heavy pike you will run slow and if your getting attacked and trying to run put away your weapon and run.BUT all in all ithis is a great game i highly recommend it hope this helped :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												Want a somewhat realistic story on medieval times? Well... this game won't exactly provide that. Ultimately, it is fun to play but they took out the concept that if you're a woman, you have a harder time. This takes out a part of the series and it is a let down since people enjoyed this concept. I feel like people got mad and they let these people have their way and took it out. Mostly, the game is fun. I enjoy using the guns in the game and they seem overpowered but the reloading is a downfall to it. Like the crossbow. Better than the bow, but you sacrafice some reload time. If you enjoyed the concept of women having a harsher time in Warband and it's something that you saw as something to benefit to your replay value and having mods in the Steam Workshop, well, I don't recommend the game. If you are a huge fan of Mount & Blade either way, then I do see this as a game for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												With Fire&Sword also builds and expands upon the highly regarded combat system from Mount&Blade:Warband. Firearms have been introduced to the battlefield, opening up exciting new play styles and options. Players can also utilize explosives for taking out groups of foes or to breach castle walls. In addition to the enhanced singleplayer mode, With Fire and Sword also provides a host of original multiplayer content including the new Captain Mode which allows players to control their own forces in online matches.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2013
												This game is based on the 1998 Polish movie "Fire and Sword".  It provides a historical backdrop for 1650's warfare in central Europe, including Cossack, Tatar, Muscovite, Polish and Swedish units and cities.  Some mods extend the map and available units too.Game is ungoddly awesome.  Something about riding a horse while shooting - it's a similar feeling to flying.  You can command units with great precision and it takes a while to master.  But what a rush to play - even though I completely suck at fighting, buidling up an army and working out the tactics is great.  The AI is is pretty good too (I'm guessing completely based on Behavior Trees).  Sometimes I play the sniper while the rest of the army is skirmishing - really hard to get in a good shot - and very satisfying when it connects.  These are ancient guns and not rifled, so they aren't very accurate from long-range.Also playing solo (no army yet) and taking out the horse of some jerk who's tearing me up - it's a big rush of adrenhaline!Economy is quite clever, where you can drive down market prices and then send caravans at a discount.  Can also take out loans in a pinch.If you quit the tutorial immediately, then it's a little more challenging to start with no money, no gun and no horse - I think this is the best way to play it.

												Main questline is somewhat lazy and kind of disappears. Game has less content than some free community made mods yet costs 10 dollars for some reason. There's also a wide variety of mods that go above and beyond like Gekokujo, Floris, Pendor, Brytenwalda, Anno Domini, and much more yet this expansion doesn't really seem to bring anything to the table like the other two expansions. Very uninteresting map, lacks detail and makes the eastern european theme very drab. All in all not really worth buying imo. Napoleonic Wars and Viking Conquest are far superior expansions while this just feels like a community mod. If it was made by a fan I'd give it a 8/10, but since its made by taleworlds and charges money, more like a 5/10 in my opinion.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2011
												I thought the addition of guns would break Mount&Blade's fine sense of balance, but I find they work surprisingly well: they're extremely powerful, but inaccurate and slow to reload, so you can't just go Rambo on everyone. There are other changes and improvements on the series' formula as well, but whether you want to get WF&S hinges entirely on whether you enjoy the guns and the setting. Personally, I find the time period and location utterly uninteresting, but if it appeals to you, then this is something you owe it to yourself to investigate. I still prefer Warband, but don't let me spoil your fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Where could I start?  There is nothing wrong with this game.  Living up to the standards I've come to expect from Paradox Interactive, this game is perfection, fine-tuned.Some say that introducing firearms ruined the game, but that isn't true.  It made it different, and people hate change.  Playing through the campaign of this game blasts you with the ideal that indeed, graphics don't need to be perfect to have a completly immersive game. Huge battles that are decently historically accurate (as far as weapons / armors go), and an excellent team-building system make this one of the epics.  A game I ALWAYS come back to.  Living the life of the gun-runner in the medieval era, or any other sort of life for that matter, makes this game great for me.  But you could approach victory however you please.So what are you waiting for?  Buy it. 10/10.
