content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Here is my thought on "Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword":Great gun reloading simulator10/10Shot directly at a guy's head and missedGot shot in the head by someone not even aiming at me11/9Now with all seriousness, the game is good. Flat, plain and simple. It's not great (aka the other two titles), it's good. Now let me explain. First of all, this game actually has  more realism than Warband did. Want me to explain? Well, back within this time period, a shot anywhere generally meant you were dead. The infection would kill you, or the musket ball, the size of a small double-sized grape, would penetrate your body and break bones, ligaments, or even veins and arteries. In other words, musket balls could kill in one shot. In fact, it is possible to die by getting shot in the foot, or even in the leg without medical treatment. The musket ball itself would cause so much damage to the veins and arteries that the person would bleed out very easily. So I do give the game realism points when it comes to the guns. The bows, I believe, are slightly underpowered, but that could be based on my own limited knowledge of the game. The AI isn't as good as Warband, no where close. I had about 40 enemy units running into a wall trying to climb up stairs that they seemed to think didn't exist. If you want more of Warband (aka "sword swinging simulator"), then don't get this game. However, if you do want large line battles with troops moving into 5 lines or so and waiting for your command to fire, then you will enjoy this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												While this game may not have the charm of M&B:Warband, it definitely scratches that itch to command an army of musket wielding troops and watch them pepper an army of idiot peasants trying to run screaming away from you.The game itself is much like the rest of the series, start out with almost nothing but the weapons and a horse you are assigned by difficulty, then complete 'quests', join a faction and try to rule the world.  A cast of semi interesting characters join you on your ride through fake history as you lay waste to the country-side.The customizable troops you can get is a nice touch, and if you get enough cash (eventually you will via plunder or trade) you can effectively travel with an army of epic geared troops, slaughtering everything in your (or your lords) name.Story?  Bah who needs one in this style of game?  Your story is the story, basically making it so you yourself get to design your own story by destroying army after army.  Or die trying.  And stuff.Open world games are easy to get lost in, and while the graphics are dated (but being able to display 200+ troops in a FPS styled RTS is impressive in it's own right) there are worse things in life.I strongly recommend this game for people who wish that M&B had muskets instead of crossbows, as while the story isn't a big leap, the combat definitely feels fresh.  Skyrim this may not be, but in Skyrim you can't honestly lead 200+ troops around attacking people/villages at random or capture yourself a few castles without some serious modding.Also look into the mods/DLC for this game if you like multiplayer, the community is pretty cool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Mount & Blade the game is a wonderful creature. I've played many hours in this franchise, throughout several games, and I am nothing short of amazed. The basis for the game is so simple, I often wonder why more developers haven't tried something like this, but then I get knocked off a siege ladder for the second consecutive time by my screaming comrades, and feel like playing Call of Duty 36.This installment is a magnificent addition to the franchise - perhaps less-so on the RTS side of it, but definitely moreso on the combat/castle siege part of it. And that's one of the most beautiful parts to the game: There are many sides to it!Though slightly more limited than some of its predecessors (mods included), WF&S is an explosive entry into an explosive era in our world history: The era of the discovery and hugely widespread use of powder weapons.Being a generally combat-based game, this is the feature which I believe shines the most -- another facet of combat.Firearms bring an entirely new level of gameplay. Crossbows had a similar feel, but the sensation of riding down fleeing cossacks and driving a pistol ball into the small of their backs is hard to replicate without the resounding BOOM of a gun. You can really feel the concussion of many of these weapons. The graphics of them are at some points breathtaking. You trot several yards toward a distant wood-hewn fort, your many ranks of men beside you, having temporarily discarded your horses, and the fog is so thick, you can still barely make out the outline of the structure, though you know you must be close now. Suddenly, cries of germanic slang echo across the misty gully in front of a suddenly evident wooden wall, and more obviously, the gunshots follow, their concussions cutting through the haze like thunderclaps.Watching the blasts of powder-powered weaponry atop the walls of a wooden fort was all I needed to justify my purchase of this game.Then I got pushed off a siege ladder again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Hesitant at first to play what looked like a clunky fps in the 1600s, especially since I knew so little about the Euro Northern wars of that time. I was so wrong. It's a delightfully fun sandbox game. Yes, it still has some bugs and the graphics hurt the eyes at times but the game play and depth is great. With only 38.7 hours into the game, I've formed a fairly competant mercenary band. Had a private rivalry with a Russian warlord that lead to me taking his fortress away after a month long siege. I started a Swedish civil war by backing a disposed queen. Succeeding in seeing her return to the throne. Strengthened the bonds of that broken nation by taking more lands from the Tzar of Russia to give to Swed nobility. Innocently started a war with the Tzar, inadvertently saving the Crimean and Polish realms from collapsing under Russian advances. Finally, got around to mastering trade routes and tending to the needs of my subjects. Took a few hours to get the handle of charging on horse back and timing sword swings to kill my foes as I rode past, but I love this game now. Oh so very very much. Commanding my intrepid band of mercs to overrun castles and forts, I don't think I'll grow tired of this game any time soon. Looking forward to a Steam sale to try out the viking and napoleonic eras of this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2011
												The only competition for Mount & Blade is another Mount & Blade.With Fire & Sword has been announced as "More M&B, now also with a story". It is basically a mod provided by the developers themselves, with a new (historical) map of Eastern Europe, new balancing and some tweaks. This is not M&B 2 or Warband 2, it is just a stand-alone Warband mod. The story takes place in a few "epic" quest chains, which offer a little more than the bare-bones open world medieval warfare simulator which the main game has always been. It is still 95% make-your-own-game open world, just spiced up a little.Be warned, difficulty is insanely high. You will try and fail many times before you even learn how to hold your own, let alone become powerful enough to win any significant battle unaided. I was originally surprised how bad the balancing and code quality were, but the post-launch patches have corrected many flaws and made it playable. Still frustratingly hard, but rewarding if you persist long enough.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2011
												A development of Warband which is almost hidden from view. The obvious changes of adding firearms and new factions hides a much deeper alteration to the mechanics of the game as a whole including the ability to create a trade infrastructure for you to generate money, work for mayors and the guilds, support claimants, or take over a faction with scripted story driven quests. The soldier experience system has also been overhauled. At first glance this is simply more of the same but a deeper investigation shows a more mature and well realised whole than Warband.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Great game. I started playing it only because Warband stopped working for me, but I'm glad I did. There is an improvement in graphics, and some of the combat mechanics such as blocking and mounted combat have also improved. The overall gameplay however, isn't as good as Warbands. Adding guns made it more fun in multiplayer, but it also increased difficulty in singleplayer, because you can easily be killed with one shot. You can't recruit people from villages anymore, you have to buy them from mercenary camps, which annoyed me, and having to pay extra to get decent equipment for your men is also a hassle. Overall it's a good game, not as good as Warband but it still has its perks. Great for multiplayer.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												It was a late night in Bread Village we had been sieged for over 10 days with continuously attacks, the men was starting to get tired and our morale was getting low. Then on the 11th day me and my men attacked the enemies base with great success but worse thing happend meanwhile, when we started to march home again you could hear the agonisingly screams from afar from the village where we lived. When we enterd the village you could se corpses lying on the ground for some reason it was only villagers from our village. We asked one of the survivors that was badly hurt and lying on the ground what had happend when we where gone, the only thing he said was "HAIL THE BREAD!" continuously while shaking. As he would said nothing more we want deeper into the village at the main hall where most of the survivor where they all stared at us and chanted "The Bread". A feel of dread slowly creeps over me. One of the survivors is my best commander and I ask him what the hell is going on. He then slowly starts walking towards me, and i notice that all other survivors are doing the same. I notice that they are all completely naked and they are all covered in flour and some of them have burnmarks on their skin. Their chants increase,"THE BREAD, THE BREAD!". I saw that in their hands they are holding big white bread loafs, and slowly one step at the time they are coming closer and my commander is holding a huge sack of flour. I start yelling "WHATS HAPPENING" but no answers are given, i cant find and escape they have surrounded me and are continuously chanting "THE BREAD!". They are so close to me i can smell the delicious bread. They suddenly stopped when they where one meter from me their chanting was starting to fade away. One of them said "What bussnies do you have with the holy bread?" i answered "what BREAD?!". The moment i said that they started furiously chanting "THE BREAD!" one of then hit me with the bread in my face. Then the chanting faded again. One of them said "The Bread is all that is holy and sacred do you offer your life for the Bread and is willing to sacrifise every thing for it. I think to myself what is this madness about this bread? the whole village has lost its mind. I screamd you are all INSANE! Then everything got dark...Based on an ingame experience10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												If heaven does exist, then this is exactly what it would be like.Jokes aside this game is crazy fun! (Depending on what kind of person you are and how you like your games roasted that is) I myself bought this game about a year ago to add it to my collection of growing games. I have even placed it in my "Favorite" section near Skyrim, Natural Selection 2 and a few other select titles that I enjoy. I hold this game very highly for every aspect it gives to the player. The graphics are far from being good but once you fall in love with the game you can't help but enjoy the not-next-gen graphics. Combat is very basic but can prove to be a nuisance at times. Charging directly towards guns that are pointed in the opposite direction that you are traveling does prove to make matters worse. But hey! It's still fun!I haven't yet begun to find myself tangled in any of the main quests as I'm too busy trying to level my player and increase the size of my party to overtake castles in the name of the Crimean Khanate! Victory for my nation will follow within the next couple hundred hours I invest into this game.In this game you do find yourself running around a lot given the fact the map of the whole game is a whole country. My advice to when you start playing, pres Ctrl + Space. It allows you to travel and wait much faster. Also makes the game less of a headache once you have to travel from Akkerman directly to Moscow (both at opposite sides of the country).During sometime after you get addicted the game does get repetitve in both positive and negative aspects. The quests that nobles give are always the same 10 or so quests the game has. The combat is also repetive in feeling that it is awesoem! You truly have full scale battles against other armies. Victroy feels satifying and Defeat feel like, well defeat. Plus it doesn't help when some of your comrades bring it up to you that you suck.Overall, I can easily say that I recommend this game. The graphics aren't pretty and the combat isn't spectacular. But time and effort you spend into your Player will be more than rewarding. You eventually become attached. You try to talk to your troops and nobles but they never listen. I've never experienced any other of the Warbands but I can gurantee I'd be in love with the others as much as I am with Fire and Sword.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												While this game may not have the charm of M&B:Warband, it definitely scratches that itch to command an army of musket wielding troops and watch them pepper an army of idiot peasants trying to run screaming away from you.The game itself is much like the rest of the series, start out with almost nothing but the weapons and a horse you are assigned by difficulty, then complete 'quests', join a faction and try to rule the world.  A cast of semi interesting characters join you on your ride through fake history as you lay waste to the country-side.The customizable troops you can get is a nice touch, and if you get enough cash (eventually you will via plunder or trade) you can effectively travel with an army of epic geared troops, slaughtering everything in your (or your lords) name.Story?  Bah who needs one in this style of game?  Your story is the story, basically making it so you yourself get to design your own story by destroying army after army.  Or die trying.  And stuff.Open world games are easy to get lost in, and while the graphics are dated (but being able to display 200+ troops in a FPS styled RTS is impressive in it's own right) there are worse things in life.I strongly recommend this game for people who wish that M&B had muskets instead of crossbows, as while the story isn't a big leap, the combat definitely feels fresh.  Skyrim this may not be, but in Skyrim you can't honestly lead 200+ troops around attacking people/villages at random or capture yourself a few castles without some serious modding.Also look into the mods/DLC for this game if you like multiplayer, the community is pretty cool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Hesitant at first to play what looked like a clunky fps in the 1600s, especially since I knew so little about the Euro Northern wars of that time. I was so wrong. It's a delightfully fun sandbox game. Yes, it still has some bugs and the graphics hurt the eyes at times but the game play and depth is great. With only 38.7 hours into the game, I've formed a fairly competant mercenary band. Had a private rivalry with a Russian warlord that lead to me taking his fortress away after a month long siege. I started a Swedish civil war by backing a disposed queen. Succeeding in seeing her return to the throne. Strengthened the bonds of that broken nation by taking more lands from the Tzar of Russia to give to Swed nobility. Innocently started a war with the Tzar, inadvertently saving the Crimean and Polish realms from collapsing under Russian advances. Finally, got around to mastering trade routes and tending to the needs of my subjects. Took a few hours to get the handle of charging on horse back and timing sword swings to kill my foes as I rode past, but I love this game now. Oh so very very much. Commanding my intrepid band of mercs to overrun castles and forts, I don't think I'll grow tired of this game any time soon. Looking forward to a Steam sale to try out the viking and napoleonic eras of this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												Mount & Blade: WFaS is an awesome game that combines the amazing gameplay from Warband with a twist of gunpowder, this minor addition alters the whole game darastically. This game is hard at first, it requires correct judgment of reach and speed whilst also challenging you to think about what direction to attack from. You can attack and parry from 4 sides, slash/parry from left, slash/parry from right, slash/parry overhead attacks as well as stab. The controls are very simple, a simple click and flick of the mouse in a particular direction will give you your attack/parry. The gameplay in this game is a mix of RPG, Strategy and Action, you will be controlling a main character, leveling them up and giving them weapons and armour. When you are in combat you will also be commanding an army (if you have decided to recruit troops) the commands are very simple, such as; hold, move up, charge and hold fire (with fire and  sword feature only).In short this game has given me hours of fun.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Story - With Fire and Sword takes place during the centurey of when humans made the very first firearms, aka Muskets, and flintlocks. Pros - Many quest. A main story line. playable. brings weapons from the very first firearms and grenades into the game. CAn be modded.Cons - Hard at the start. keep getting attacked by a deserter that you have paided to have passage. Guns can be one shot one kill. Hard to advance through the game. Hard to keep an army alive. bugs/gliches to where you have to restart the game. sometimes loss of save data. Items are too expensive. Personal Review - Could be a whole lot better. Was expecting more of a game with the Mount&Blade Title. Then again, wasnt made by TaleWorlds I suppose. Fair start into a game already with a main quest and other things. But you are forced to play through the tutorial EVERY TIME you make a new character. This game is not as good as I was expecting, I play it from time to time, but its nothing like Warband, and never will be. Armour is too expensive to get, and Deserters are too over powered are the beginning of the game.I recommend this game if you are looking for a game with some difficulty, even though you can set it to easy, it will still be hard.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I was an avid player of warband, having logged many hours even before I bought the steam version.  (I would guess something like 1000 hours in warband)  regardless, I got the collector pack even though I owned warband already just to try this... mod.  The game removes alot of content that I liked about warband.  marriage and courtship have been removed.  You play for what seems like a very long time and then cant join a faction.  (buggy and broke)  No matter how high level you get a lvl 1 peon can one shot you with a musket if you are not contantly weaving on your horse to the point of sore hand joints.  Generating money in this game feels like work compared to warband.  You can't recruit units from villages anymore and train them up.  You can go to merc camps and buy soliders but they have a limited amount.  Even when your mercs level up through training and battle you have to pay to upgrade them, and it's no small amount.  Bottom line is take out most of what is fun about warband and then you get this.  It feels like work, not a game.  Anything battle over say... 1/3 your forces is almost impossible.  I once too out 120 troops with a 78 highly trained merc fighting force, to get garbage drops.  Best is like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ +3 cloth boots.  Are you kidding me?  What about that lord I just face♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  I don't play on easy but even if you do you can still be one shotted, start of game or accomplished vet doesn't matter.  Frustrating game.  Quests are weak sauce too.  Deliver this message to (insert lord from other faction here who we are at war with) ... well WTF would I deliver stuff to someone i'm trying to kill?  How come you don't know the password for your own treasure?? (slight spoiler)  Don't buy this game.  Stick with warband and it's awsome mod community.

												If you liked the previous Mount and Blade: Warband title, I recommend this one too. If you have not played that one, I highly suggest playing that before getting this one. Posted: July 25, 2011
												The only competition for Mount & Blade is another Mount & Blade.With Fire & Sword has been announced as "More M&B, now also with a story". It is basically a mod provided by the developers themselves, with a new (historical) map of Eastern Europe, new balancing and some tweaks. This is not M&B 2 or Warband 2, it is just a stand-alone Warband mod. The story takes place in a few "epic" quest chains, which offer a little more than the bare-bones open world medieval warfare simulator which the main game has always been. It is still 95% make-your-own-game open world, just spiced up a little.Be warned, difficulty is insanely high. You will try and fail many times before you even learn how to hold your own, let alone become powerful enough to win any significant battle unaided. I was originally surprised how bad the balancing and code quality were, but the post-launch patches have corrected many flaws and made it playable. Still frustratingly hard, but rewarding if you persist long enough.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2011
												At first I was frustrated with the release of another stand alone from Tale Worlds, as I thought it would divert attention from their previous games and would I would have to pay for a whole new game. I also didn't see the point as there were mods for M&B and Warband that add most of the things that WFaS add, but I must say that no mods do it quite as nicely as WFaS. Graphically it is superior to all mods out there and there are some new features that are nice. The outfitting of mercenaries was a little awkward, so if that's a key point for you, you might look past this one. Overall though I would recommend it especially as a fan of the series, it is really well polished in comparison to mods of the same type for the previous games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2011
												Fire and Sword adds only what is seen in the pictures. It takes away every feature that made Warband accessible and enjoyable.  Tournaments, Productive Enterprises, Plunder and razing of villages, new faction creation from captured castles, recruiting from villages (replaced with a Mercenary Camp at every faction), and the ability to have a marriage. I played this enough to realize this is a downgrade not an upgrade. The map in singlepalyer is dull, mountainless, and has the same skirmish map for nearly every encounter. Guns in their current state are realistic in the fact that they destroy your health bar. This can be a very heavy imbalance when you cannot gain money to buy armor, buy recruits, and equipment. My friends and I could not have fathomed how disappointed we would be when we actually played the game. If you want a warband that has muskets and a historical setting, try Old Frontier 1755. I am only voicing my honest opinion.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2012
												This game is a standalone xpac for one of my all time favorite franchises, Mount & Blade, but with historical factions and guns.  The fighting takes place in the 1650s during the Cossack uprising in Poland.  The game was a bit of a disappointment at release, due to some missing features (especially if you're coming from M&B: Warband) and a lot of bugs.  Its still buggy but its playable, especially with mods.  The SP is more story/quest driven than Warband, but make no mistake that its a sandbox game.  My favorite addition that it brings to the table is MP Captain mode, which allows you to control a squad of bots against other players or fight alongside them in cooperative mode.  This mode is actually really great; its fun to use your SP squad skills in MP, but there aren't a lot of people playing it anymore.  Overall Its a flawed game, but still a good one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												Mount & Blade: WFaS is an awesome game that combines the amazing gameplay from Warband with a twist of gunpowder, this minor addition alters the whole game darastically. This game is hard at first, it requires correct judgment of reach and speed whilst also challenging you to think about what direction to attack from. You can attack and parry from 4 sides, slash/parry from left, slash/parry from right, slash/parry overhead attacks as well as stab. The controls are very simple, a simple click and flick of the mouse in a particular direction will give you your attack/parry. The gameplay in this game is a mix of RPG, Strategy and Action, you will be controlling a main character, leveling them up and giving them weapons and armour. When you are in combat you will also be commanding an army (if you have decided to recruit troops) the commands are very simple, such as; hold, move up, charge and hold fire (with fire and  sword feature only).In short this game has given me hours of fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												If heaven does exist, then this is exactly what it would be like.Jokes aside this game is crazy fun! (Depending on what kind of person you are and how you like your games roasted that is) I myself bought this game about a year ago to add it to my collection of growing games. I have even placed it in my "Favorite" section near Skyrim, Natural Selection 2 and a few other select titles that I enjoy. I hold this game very highly for every aspect it gives to the player. The graphics are far from being good but once you fall in love with the game you can't help but enjoy the not-next-gen graphics. Combat is very basic but can prove to be a nuisance at times. Charging directly towards guns that are pointed in the opposite direction that you are traveling does prove to make matters worse. But hey! It's still fun!I haven't yet begun to find myself tangled in any of the main quests as I'm too busy trying to level my player and increase the size of my party to overtake castles in the name of the Crimean Khanate! Victory for my nation will follow within the next couple hundred hours I invest into this game.In this game you do find yourself running around a lot given the fact the map of the whole game is a whole country. My advice to when you start playing, pres Ctrl + Space. It allows you to travel and wait much faster. Also makes the game less of a headache once you have to travel from Akkerman directly to Moscow (both at opposite sides of the country).During sometime after you get addicted the game does get repetitve in both positive and negative aspects. The quests that nobles give are always the same 10 or so quests the game has. The combat is also repetive in feeling that it is awesoem! You truly have full scale battles against other armies. Victroy feels satifying and Defeat feel like, well defeat. Plus it doesn't help when some of your comrades bring it up to you that you suck.Overall, I can easily say that I recommend this game. The graphics aren't pretty and the combat isn't spectacular. But time and effort you spend into your Player will be more than rewarding. You eventually become attached. You try to talk to your troops and nobles but they never listen. I've never experienced any other of the Warbands but I can gurantee I'd be in love with the others as much as I am with Fire and Sword.

												Some might call this the black sheep of the series because of the plain and repetitive pattern on the mapscreen and in the towns/villages but this is what this game has that the other didn't have. GUNS n' GRENADES. You are pinned down behind a weak pine tree. You've taken out every cavalry the enemy lord had to send by his riflemen got your number. And what is it that caused your death behind that tree? THEIR GUNS. Another example, you are up against a big stack o' baddies and are armed to their teeth with swords and sturdy armor. What did you use to reduce their platoon to a meat rain? That's rite. GRENADES. But some might also nitpick on the swinging controls and such but personally I don't see that as a problem. To me, Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword have got everything the other ones had and more to it. 8 outta 10 :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I was an avid player of warband, having logged many hours even before I bought the steam version.  (I would guess something like 1000 hours in warband)  regardless, I got the collector pack even though I owned warband already just to try this... mod.  The game removes alot of content that I liked about warband.  marriage and courtship have been removed.  You play for what seems like a very long time and then cant join a faction.  (buggy and broke)  No matter how high level you get a lvl 1 peon can one shot you with a musket if you are not contantly weaving on your horse to the point of sore hand joints.  Generating money in this game feels like work compared to warband.  You can't recruit units from villages anymore and train them up.  You can go to merc camps and buy soliders but they have a limited amount.  Even when your mercs level up through training and battle you have to pay to upgrade them, and it's no small amount.  Bottom line is take out most of what is fun about warband and then you get this.  It feels like work, not a game.  Anything battle over say... 1/3 your forces is almost impossible.  I once too out 120 troops with a 78 highly trained merc fighting force, to get garbage drops.  Best is like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ +3 cloth boots.  Are you kidding me?  What about that lord I just face♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  I don't play on easy but even if you do you can still be one shotted, start of game or accomplished vet doesn't matter.  Frustrating game.  Quests are weak sauce too.  Deliver this message to (insert lord from other faction here who we are at war with) ... well WTF would I deliver stuff to someone i'm trying to kill?  How come you don't know the password for your own treasure?? (slight spoiler)  Don't buy this game.  Stick with warband and it's awsome mod community.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												M&B: With Fire & Sword is my favourite game out of the Mount & Series. It's more or less an RPG set during the Deluge in Eastern Europe in the 1600s. Join an army, or rebel against the powers including Poland, Sweden & Russia. My favourite part of the game is slowly developing your character in a way that is similar to that of The Elder Scrolls games (skills, inventory, quests, etc,.) and travelling across the map to hire soldiers and unique mecernaries for your army.I had one problem with the game and that was completing the main quest which proved impossible as I didn't follow the instructions properly, didn't complete the required tasks in a specific amount of time or committed actions earlier which halted the development of the story. I could not complete the game from this point and had to start again, it's wise to save your game before undertaking big quests.Despite the story problem, I love this game and I had alot of fun playing it!8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Great game. I started playing it only because Warband stopped working for me, but I'm glad I did. There is an improvement in graphics, and some of the combat mechanics such as blocking and mounted combat have also improved. The overall gameplay however, isn't as good as Warbands. Adding guns made it more fun in multiplayer, but it also increased difficulty in singleplayer, because you can easily be killed with one shot. You can't recruit people from villages anymore, you have to buy them from mercenary camps, which annoyed me, and having to pay extra to get decent equipment for your men is also a hassle. Overall it's a good game, not as good as Warband but it still has its perks. Great for multiplayer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2011
												The only competition for Mount & Blade is another Mount & Blade.With Fire & Sword has been announced as "More M&B, now also with a story". It is basically a mod provided by the developers themselves, with a new (historical) map of Eastern Europe, new balancing and some tweaks. This is not M&B 2 or Warband 2, it is just a stand-alone Warband mod. The story takes place in a few "epic" quest chains, which offer a little more than the bare-bones open world medieval warfare simulator which the main game has always been. It is still 95% make-your-own-game open world, just spiced up a little.Be warned, difficulty is insanely high. You will try and fail many times before you even learn how to hold your own, let alone become powerful enough to win any significant battle unaided. I was originally surprised how bad the balancing and code quality were, but the post-launch patches have corrected many flaws and made it playable. Still frustratingly hard, but rewarding if you persist long enough.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This iteration of M&B adds guns (pistols, muskets) as well as a new map with new factions (not fantasy - Cossacks, Crimeans, Muscovites. Poles, and Swedes). As a result, much of the game's presentation is historical in nature. You'll see references to people like Jan Sobieski and Cardinal Richelieu. Nonetheless, WFAS still enables the same level of flexibility as other M&B games. Want to be a bandit? Sure. King? Done. Trader? At your leisure.If I had to voice any complaints it would be that there are no tournaments (RIP ez cash farming) and no marriage system. Highly recommend.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												As good as any other Mount&Blade game, i mean really good.In my opinion rifles being added to game isn't that bad. Yes, they are a bit overpowered because you can reload them while moving, however if you look up the k/d lists in servers, you can see that players with the best scores are always playing melee. I play this game since it is published and it was same back then. I think that this game has great multiplayer and still not filled with auto-blockers like Warband MP.About the singleplayer, I think it is really good but really difficult. I only played Cossack Hetmanate and Polish Commonwealth campaigns(there is also Russian campaign which is also awesome). Even though they are very difficult as you should be always prepared and often encounter unfair battles, they are lots of fun and well planned by the developers.My overall score is 9.5/10 also considering its price. For this price, it is one of the best games you can have and a game that you will never ever regret buying.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Here is my thought on "Mount & Blade: With Fire and Sword":Great gun reloading simulator10/10Shot directly at a guy's head and missedGot shot in the head by someone not even aiming at me11/9Now with all seriousness, the game is good. Flat, plain and simple. It's not great (aka the other two titles), it's good. Now let me explain. First of all, this game actually has  more realism than Warband did. Want me to explain? Well, back within this time period, a shot anywhere generally meant you were dead. The infection would kill you, or the musket ball, the size of a small double-sized grape, would penetrate your body and break bones, ligaments, or even veins and arteries. In other words, musket balls could kill in one shot. In fact, it is possible to die by getting shot in the foot, or even in the leg without medical treatment. The musket ball itself would cause so much damage to the veins and arteries that the person would bleed out very easily. So I do give the game realism points when it comes to the guns. The bows, I believe, are slightly underpowered, but that could be based on my own limited knowledge of the game. The AI isn't as good as Warband, no where close. I had about 40 enemy units running into a wall trying to climb up stairs that they seemed to think didn't exist. If you want more of Warband (aka "sword swinging simulator"), then don't get this game. However, if you do want large line battles with troops moving into 5 lines or so and waiting for your command to fire, then you will enjoy this game.

Posted: July 9, 2011
												Si je le recommande c'est surtout pour son univers particulier et surtout pour la série Mount and Blade. Imaginez, il y a plusieurs royaumes, vous n'êtes qu'un vagabond avec une armée de mercenaires, vous vous faites attaquez par quelques bandits et vous pillez quelques villages. Enfin c'est un des nombreux scénarios de départ, vous pouvez vous faire remarquer par un royaume et ainsi être un seigneur de celui-ci ou créer votre royaume en possédant des châteaux ou des villes. Les seules limites que vous avez c'est votre niveau d'expérience qui influencera le tout: votre armée, votre équipement, vos compagnons qui peuvent aussi évoluer, vos relations avec les royaumes, les quêtes ainsi que vos capacités sur le champ de bataille avec différentes armes, vous préférez foncer dans le tas avec une lance et un cheval ou attaquer à pied avec un bon gros fusil ? Vous vivez vraiment une aventure et vous y passerez des heures avant d'être riche et roi, je vous le garantis !

												Although this game isn't as good as Mount and Blade Warband in my opinion, it still is good and I recommend you should buy it. The good thing about this game is the fact that it has firearms which are pretty OP in battle but the long reload time means that it would be helpful to have a sword with you just in case. The gameplay is just as nice as in the other games with great mechanics involving horses and guns and all weopan types making this a pretty releastic and action-packed game. Although there can be a few A.I. problems and you will run into the occasional texture glitch in battle and on the map, it will still be a fun game if you like Medeival action and strategy along with RPG and a few shooter elements.Here is the final score:Gameplay: 8.5/10 (If you like the genre)Story: 7/10 (Mostly sandbox which is fun but it has a storyline)Multiplayer: 8/10 (Hard if you're new but you will get better, multiplayer is only battles)Graphics: 7/10 (Well it's a strategy game)OVERALL: 8/10Pretty good, a must buy if you like Medeival Strategy and action games and you should try it out if you're new to playing these types of games but i recoment you buy Mount and Blade: Warband first.

												Mount&Blade With Fire And Sword is a Action RPG in First or Third Person.It's also the first Game in the Series to move from the Crusade's into the 17th Century.In This world You will Encounter many follower's that you can Recruit,Arm,and Custimize to your liking,including yourself.You may Conquer your own Castle,Village,or Fortress and Grow More Powerful and Known.This time around,you can use FireArms,including Rifles,Muskets,Pistols,and even Grenades,but you can still always use the Classic Sword, Halberd, Spear, or Throwing Knifes too Bow And Arrows on your Trusty Horse.The Story doesn't really start Until you Choose what Faction to join,there is many Factions,but only three Main Storylines,with Plenty Of side-quest and Multiple endings.The Playable Historical Factions are Poland,Ukraine,Russia,Sweden and the Crimean Khanate,each with there own Banners,unique Style's,Armor,ETC.GamePlay:9.0Story:8.5Replay:HighBuy:YesMultiPlayer:YesYou Can Read The Full Review At My WebSite

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												NOTE: If you are reading this BEFORE buying the game, buy M&B Warband first. The learning curve for new players is almost vertical if you haven't spent a fair amount of time in M&B Warband first.Mount and Blade: With Fire and Sword is game set in 1600's Europe. It is completely historically accurate, and has new weapons different from it's big brother Warband. These weapons include: Muskets, Carbines, Pistols, and Bombs. This also means that all types of weapons from Warband are in this game as well. The game starts out and asks you to make some chocies. Of course, no matter which choices you choose, you will always be put in the tutorial at the beginning of every new game. You start fighting bandits to learn the swordfighting mechanics. After that you find a man named Jacque de Clermont who helps you fight the bandits. Then, you all get on horses and fight some more bandits in order to learn the horse mechanics. But after that, you talk to Jacque a little more and are left to your own devices. This is why the learning curve is vertical for new players. There are more bandits/looters/brigands for every area than there are in Warband, and i learned that the hard way. You'll be getting killed a lot and will have no idea what to do for a while. Now, on to my opinions on the game. I think that this game is the best game for swordfighting and primitive guns usage in any game ever. There. I just do. The mechanics feel nice, look nice, and when you get a bunch of perfect blocks against a Winged Hussar with a Lance and you only have a saber, it feels so good. The battles are fun and engaging, and when you have a decent party and engage in a battle, you'll ususally be looking forward to it. Of course, there is also the ruler part. For a long time you'll be independent, but when you kill the subject of a king or ruler, any nations that are warring with that king you can now join to be a subject. After that, when you lead a seige you can capture enemy strongholds and forts for them to be your own. I don't think you can become the leader of a nation or create a new nation in this one like you can in Warband.Now the flaws. First, it doesn't look too good. I think it looks okay, but most people don't and will be driven away by this fact. It also is buggy. Every once and a while certain bugs will happen that will make you SO MAD.All in all, i rate9/10 Fantasic game, but has it's flaws.
